bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, October 1, 1941

div1.p: Hench commends Truby on his wonderful manuscript.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, October 1, 1941
div1.opener:
October 1, 1941
General A. E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
My dear General Truby:
div1.p:
Just a brief note. I am immersed in the final preparation of
our Rheumatism Review and have been delayed in answering your last two
letters.

I am sending by separate post a copy of the current Hygeia.
Shortly I will have many reprints available and will be glad to give you
as many as you wish. General Kean has asked me to send you a few items
which he recently loaned to me. They will be copied and sent to you this
week.

Just yesterday I received your second manuscript. What a tre-
mendous improvement it is on the first one. It is really wonderful and
simply must be published. I felt lousy yesterday with a cold, a left
frontal sinusitis, a very sore threat and a nasty disposition. Last night
I picked up your manuscript at ten o'clock to read over a few pages. I
forgot all about my illness and finished reading it at ten minutes of 3 A.M.,
having read it carefully and having made a number of suggestions which I
will send to you shortly after I have reread the manuscript.

Dr. Pinto seems to be entirely friendly. Apparently, your
fears on that score were groundless. I have not yet written him but plan
to do so shortly and hope to visit him enroute to California in February.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
